name: System Collapse
description: Following the events in Network Effect, the Barish-Estranza corporation has sent rescue ships to a newly-colonized planet in peril, as well as additional SecUnits. But if there's an ethical corporation out there, Murderbot has yet to find it, and if Barish-Estranza can't have the planet, they're sure as hell not leaving without something. If that something just happens to be an entire colony of humans, well, a free workforce is a decent runner-up prize.

But there's something wrong with Murderbot; it isn't running within normal operational parameters. ART's crew and the humans from Preservation are doing everything they can to protect the colonists, but with Barish-Estranza's SecUnit-heavy persuasion teams, they're going to have to hope Murderbot figures out what's wrong with itself, and fast.
review: As Fugitive telemetry didn't exactly continue from Network Effect I assumed this one would also be in a different direction but to my surprise this book actually picks up right where Network Effect left off which makes it exciting to see the direct aftermath of those events.

In "System Collapse" our beloved SecUnit continues its adventures with both familiar faces and new challenges. After the high stakes drama where our Murderbot dealt with alien remnants and Three's manipulation, this new chapter dives deeper into the consequences of those encounters. The story explores how murderbot handles the complicated relationships it formed with Dr. Mensah's group and especially with ART, whose partnership has become one of the most entertaining dynamis in the series.

The central conflict revolves around the fallout from previous events, with corporate interests and political machinations creating new dangers that require all of Murderbot's tactical skills and reluctant emotional intelligence. The plot weaves together action sequences with quieter moments of introspection that become hallmarks of Well's storytelling.

Without giving more the plot away, there are some genuinely surprising twists that made me gasp - moments where the author takes the narrative in directions I never imagined coming. The worldbuilding expands further, giving us more glimpses into the complex corporate dominated universe that makes this series so fascinating.

The supporting cast shines brightly too. Their evolving relationships with Murderbot provide both heartwarming moments and complications that drive the plot forward. The dialogue remains sharp, witty and often hilarious despite the high stakes.

As the last book of the series, I was wondering how they would end it, and it was not bad. You start to see a kind of pattern to the books once u have read 4-5 but it doesn't make it boring (at least didn't do it for me). I would suggest this series to anyone who likes Sci-fi.

name: Fugitive Telemetry
description: When Murderbot discovers a dead body on Preservation Station, it knows it is going to have to assist station security to determine who the body is (was), how they were killed (that should be relatively straightforward, at least), and why (because apparently that matters to a lot of people—who knew?)
Yes, the unthinkable is about to happen: Murderbot must voluntarily speak to humans!
review: After finishing Network Effect, This novel Fugitive Telemetry, the 6th one in the series of Murderbot, takes a completely different direction. It's the usual our SecUnit hanging out in Preservation chilling and trying to avoid unnecessary human interaction but suddenly something comes up which disrupts our murderbot's routine. This time the murderbot is asked to play detective, working with the station's security to solve the problem.

What makes this book particularly entertaining is that our murderbot has to cooperate with local law enforcement. I cannot imagine our socially awkward, protocol-hating SecUnit trying to follow proper investigative procedures. It is as hilarious as it sounds. This one gives us a different flavor of murderbot adventure. Instead of our usual high-stakes space action, we get to see the SecUnit applying its security expertise as it does in its name itself. It's like CSI in space but with more sarcasm.

The station setting allows us to really dig into the daily life of Preservation, something we have only glimpsed before. We get to see how regular humans live in this world, how security actually works when there isn't a crisis, and how Murderbot fits (or doesn't fit) into this relatively peaceful society. It's really fascinating to watch the murderbot navigate station politics and bureaucracy. Our SecUnit might be great at hacking systems and fighting bad guys, but dealing with paperwork and following proper channels? That's another level of challenge.

The mystery itself is delightfully twisty, with plenty of red herrings and surprising developments. You'll find yourself trying to piece together the clues alongside the protagonist, though it's probably better at it then we mere humans would be.

Without giving anything away, I can say that Martha Wells continues to expand on the themes of identity, belonging and what it means to be a part of a community. We get to see new sides of the murderbot as it tries to balance its natural inclination for surveillance and security with the station's more open society. It was a really fun novel for me personally, just don't expect the murderbot to be thrilled about filing incident reports.

name: Network Effect
description: It calls itself Murderbot, but only when no one can hear. It worries about the fragile human crew who've grown to trust it, but only where no one can see. It tells itself that they're only a professional obligation, but when they're captured and an old friend from the past requires urgent assistance, Murderbot must choose between inertia and drastic action.
Drastic action it is, then.
review: It had been a really really long time since I last read the murderbot series. It was a treat. This is the 5th book in the series by Martha wells. There is a very short filler book called Home: Habitat, Range, Niche, Territory before this which is considered to be the 4.5th one. Its length is almost just as much of a chapter. I would suggest you read all the prequels before jumping into this one.

So imagine this: Murderbot's actually gotten somewhat comfortable working with the human clients (I know, shocking right? But somewhat to be expected after the previous 4 books). It's doing its usual thing, protecting humans while trying to maintain its optimal media watching schedule. But of course, the universe has its own plans.

This book continues after the previous book with a present situation while showing glimpses of why the current situation ended up being that way. After all the experiences our murderbot had, this one was surprising to its own standards. I had considered that I would be able to guess what this book might be about, but failed to do so. The story continues in Preservation Aux with the original crew when something drastic happens when the murderbot and its humans are suddenly abducted.

The best part in this book is how the murderbot tries to tackle something with the most humanistic way possible, even though that's what the SecUnit hates the most, it is forced to do so. I loved the way the story was told with the amount of chaos and action involved. This particular adventure brings back someone our murderbot never expected to see again. (If you have read "Artificial Condition", you might have an idea who I'm talking about). With the introduction of new characters which we were waiting for, maybe not everyone but I was definitely waiting for it, it added a lot of depth and contrast.

This time we are not dealing with corporate espionage or security threats anymore, we face abandoned colonies, strange technology and threats that could have implications far beyond one station or planet. We already know how our Secunit always insists that it doesn't care about humans? Well this adventure puts that claim to the test. Plus there's a whole new dynamic when it has to work with other AI and bots.

Without spoiling anything, I can say that "Network Effect" has everything we love about murderbot - the snarky commentary, the reluctant heroics, the media references - but on a bigger scale. The action sequences are more elaborate, the mysteries more complex and the emotional stakes higher than ever. The longer formats allow wells to really explore some of the deeper themes that were touched in the novels. We get to delve into questions about autonomy, identity and what it means to be human in a world where the lines between organic and artificial are increasingly blurry.

name: The Good Girl's Guide to Murder
description: Everyone in Fairview knows the story.

Pretty and popular high school senior Andie Bell was murdered by her boyfriend, Sal Singh, who then killed himself. It was all anyone could talk about. And five years later, Pip sees how the tragedy still haunts her town.
But she can't shake the feeling that there was more to what happened that day. She knew Sal when she was a child, and he was always so kind to her. How could he possibly have been a killer?
review: Alright, buckle up! If you have read "Kill Joy", you're in for a real treat with "A Good Girl's Guide to Murder". This book takes everything you loved about Pippa's investigating skills and cranks it up to eleven. Even If you haven'read the prequel the fun isn't any less. This novel is the second novel by Holly Jackson

So, here's the deal: 5 years ago, a girl vanished from the small town of Little Kilton. Everyone thinks they know what happened - her boyfriend, supposedly killed her and then took his own life. Case closed, right? Well, not if you hear the name Pippa Fitz-Amobi.

Pip, our brilliant and determined protagonist, isn't convinced that the boyfriend's guilty. She decides to dig into this cold case for her final year project, and let me tell you, she's opening up one heck of a can of worms. As she starts poking around, asking questions that no one's dared to ask for years, she begins to uncover secrets that some people would prefer stayed buried.

The story unfolds through a mix of Pip's investigation logs, interviews, and good old-fashioned narrative. It's like you're right there with her, piecing together the clues and trying to figure out what really happened to Andie Bell. The project turns into a documentary of sorts. The deeper Pip digs, the more dangerous things become. It turns out that small towns can hold big secrets, and not everyone's happy about Pip stirring up the past. She soon finds herself in over her head, facing threats and obstacles she never anticipated.

The book keeps you on your toes with its clever plot twists and red herrings. Just when you think you've got it all figured out, Holly Jackson throws another curveball your way. It's the kind of story that'll have you staying up way too late, promising yourself "just one more chapter" until suddenly it's 3 AM and you've finished the whole thing. Its exactly what happened with me.

What's really exciting is seeing how Pip has grown since the events of "Kill Joy". Her experience at that murder mystery party was just the beginning. Now, she's taking on a real mystery with real stakes, and it's fascinating to see how she applies her skills in a high-pressure situation.

The supporting cast is equally intriguing. From Pip's friends and family to the various townspeople she interviews, each character adds another layer to the mystery. And of course, there's the question of the supposed murderer and his family - are they victims of a terrible mistake, or is there more to their story?

As the investigation progresses, the line between past and present starts to blur. The events of five years ago begin to have very real consequences in the here and now, and Pip finds herself racing against time to uncover the truth before it's too late.

I would gladly recommend this book to anyone who wants a bit of mystery thriller. There were some parts where I was like why in the world would you be this dumb for some characters but as I continued that feeling subsided. I would give this a 4.8 to be specific.

name: Kill Joy
description: Find out where it all started for Pip in this prequel novella to the A Good Girl's Guide to Murder.

Pippa Fitz-Amobi is not in the mood for her friend's murder mystery party. Especially one that involves 1920's fancy dress and pretending that their town, Little Kilton, is an island called Joy. But when the game begins, Pip finds herself drawn into the make-believe world of intrigue, deception and murder. But as Pip plays detective, teasing out the identity of the killer clue-by-clue, the murder of the fictional Reginald Remy isn't the only case on her mind ... Contains mature content, for older readers.
review: Honestly I didn't even know this book existed until I went to goodreads and searched Good girl's guide to murder and saw this as 0.5, and I was like ooo prequel and started this. For intro Kill Joy is a novel by Holly Jackson which was written as a prequel to A Good Girl's Guide to Murder and if you have already read it then you are in for a treat.

So we all might know already or yet to the protagonist Pippa aka pip, So she can sometimes be a bit of a killjoy (not me the title itself says it). This novel consists a group of friends trying to solve a fake murder as a mystery house party, and our determined pip is trying to solve it before anyone else, trying to be an overachiever which however suits her.

Before I start speaking too much about the actual story, lets just say that pip's detective skills are put to test in a way she was not expecting. Its like she started to give the fake murder a life of its own which started to stare back at her.

The story is a pack of twist and turns with more than enough suspense to make you want to sleep with lights on. Based on the next books title, if you want see pip's investigative skills beforehand, this book is basically a golden ticket to it. It's like getting a behind the scene pass to some characters origin story as a detective.

You can either choose to attend this fake murder mystery part and continue on with journey with the next books but if you choose to go ahead just remember if you hear "The butler did it" don't think the story ended there, In fact it might be a new beginning. The only reason my rating to this one is a 4 not because of the book itself but just imagining being pip is what made me give it.

name: Treasure Island
description: Climb aboard for the swashbuckling adventure of a lifetime. Treasure Islandhas enthralled (and caused slight seasickness) for decades. The names Long John Silver and Jim Hawkins are destined to remain pieces of folklore for as long as children want to read Robert Louis Stevenson's most famous book. With it's dastardly plot and motley crew of rogues and villains, it seems unlikely that children will ever say no to this timeless classic
review: Oh, "Treasure Island"! You're in for a treat with this classic adventure tale. It's fantastic that you're diving into the world of classical literature, and what a great place to start! The reason I picked as my first classical book was because of the "The Mysterious Island" movie and the mention of the treasure island book in it.

So, let's talk about this swashbuckling story that's captured readers' imaginations for over a century. Robert Louis Stevenson takes us on a thrilling journey filled with pirates, treasure maps, and high-seas adventure. It's the kind of book that makes you want to grab a spyglass and set sail for distant shores! And I can live this up in "Sea of thieves" its a game for those who are wondering what is it.

The story follows young Jim Hawkins, our plucky protagonist, who finds himself thrust into an incredible adventure when a mysterious old sailor shows up at his family's inn. From there, it's a whirlwind of secret maps, mutinous crews, and the search for buried treasure on a remote island. What's really cool about "Treasure Island" is how it set the standard for so many pirate stories that came after. You know all those pirate tropes you see in movies? A lot of them started right here! One-legged pirates with parrots on their shoulders? Yep, that's "Treasure Island" for you.

The characters in this book are unforgettable. There's Jim, of course, but the real star of the show is Long John Silver. He's the kind of complex villain that you can't help but be fascinated by. Is he good? Is he bad? You'll spend a good chunk of the book trying to figure that out!

The reason it took me six months to finish - classical literature can be a bit of a challenge if you're not used to the style. The language might feel a bit old-fashioned at times, but that's part of its charm but it definitely took its time with me. It's like stepping into a time machine and experiencing the adventure as readers did when it was first published in 1883. There were time when I read a page which I thought I understood and when I reached the end of page, had to re read it again to get it.

What's really impressive about "Treasure Island" is how it manages to be both a rollicking adventure story and a coming-of-age tale. We see Jim grow from a wide-eyed boy to a young man who's learned some hard lessons about trust, bravery, and morality.

The way Stevenson builds tension throughout the book is masterful. There are moments of quiet suspense that suddenly explode into action, keeping you on your toes. And the descriptions of the island itself? They're so vivid you can almost feel the sand between your toes and hear the waves crashing on the shore.

I'm glad I found it interesting despite the time it took to read. That's the thing about classics - they often reward patience (hope thats the case with all of them). There are layers to the story that you might not catch at first, but you'll get it over time.

"Treasure Island" isn't just a great adventure story - it's a book that's influenced countless other tales. From "Pirates of the Caribbean" to "Treasure Planet", you can see echoes of Stevenson's work everywhere in pop culture. If you are someone who just finished a classic, Who knows? This might be the start of a whole new reading adventure for you. Just be warned - you might find yourself saying "Shiver me timbers!" more often than usual after this one though!

name: Exit Strategy
description: Murderbot wasn't programmed to care. So, its decision to help the only human who ever showed it respect must be a system glitch, right?

Having traveled the width of the galaxy to unearth details of its own murderous transgressions, as well as those of the GrayCris Corporation, Murderbot is heading home to help Dr. Mensah—its former owner (protector? friend?)—submit evidence that could prevent GrayCris from destroying more colonists in its never-ending quest for profit.

But who's going to believe a SecUnit gone rogue?
And what will become of it when it's caught?
review: Hey there, fellow Murderbot fan! (I hope so) The book that follows "Rogue Protocol" is "Exit Strategy". So, "Exit Strategy" picks up right where "Rogue Protocol" left off, and let me tell you, it's crazy! Our favorite snarky SecUnit is back, and this time it's personal. Well, more personal than usual, if you can believe it.

Remember all that evidence Murderbot's been gathering against the corporation? Well, it's finally time to put it to use. But here's the kicker - Murderbot's human friends from the first book are in danger because of this very same evidence. Talk about a moral dilemma for our not-so-emotionless protagonist! This book brings Murderbot full circle, back to where it all began. We're talking high-stakes corporate espionage, dangerous rescue missions, and enough action to make even Murderbot's extensive media library seem lame in comparison.

What's really cool about "Exit Strategy" is how it showcases Murderbot's growth. All those experiences from the previous books (hope you've read them)? They're put to the test here. We get to see Murderbot using not just its combat skills, but also its newfound understanding of humans and its own emerging humanity to navigate some seriously tricky situations.

And oh boy, does Martha know how to ramp up the tension! There are moments in this book where you'll be holding your breath, wondering how on earth (or off-earth, as the situation may be) Murderbot is going to get out of this one. But don't worry, it's not all nail-biting suspense. Murderbot's dry humor and social awkwardness are still there giving a laugh here and there, providing some much-needed comic relief. There are moments that'll have you chuckling even as you're on the edge of your seat.

One of the things I love most about this book is how it show Murderbot's relationships - both with humans and with other artificial beings. It's fascinating to see how our dear murderbot, who started out just wanting to be left alone to watch its shows, has evolved.

The world-building continues to be top-notch, giving us an even clearer picture of this complex, corporate-dominated future. So, buckle up for another wild ride with Murderbot. "Exit Strategy" is like the season finale of your favorite show - thrilling, emotional, and leaving you eager for more.
synopsis: Murderbot wasn't programmed to care. So, its decision to help the only human who ever showed it respect must be a system glitch, right?

name: Rogue Protocol
description: SciFi's favorite antisocial A.I. is again on a mission. The case against the too-big-to-fail GrayCris Corporation is floundering, and more importantly, authorities are beginning to ask more questions about where Dr. Mensah's SecUnit is.
And Murderbot would rather those questions went away. For good.
review: Rogue Protocol is the third in the series of the Murderbot diaries. So, our favorite SecUnit is back at it again, and this time it's diving headfirst into a new mission. Murderbot's still on its quest to gather evidence against the nefarious Corporation, but now it's taking a more proactive approach. Instead of just digging into its past, Murderbot's decided to investigate one of the organiztion's abandoned terraforming projects. Talk about stepping out of your comfort zone!

This investigation leads Murderbot to a distant planet where things are definitely not as they seem. The facility's supposed to be abandoned, but surprise, surprise - there are humans there! And where there are humans, there's bound to be trouble for our socially awkward protagonist. Now, remember how Murderbot had to pretend to be human in the last book? Well, it's upping its game this time. It's posing as a security consultant, which means even more human interaction. I can almost hear Murderbot's internal groan from here!

But wait, there's more! This book introduces us to a new bot character named Miki. Without giving too much away, let's just say that Miki's presence forces Murderbot to confront some uncomfortable truths about itself and its relationships with humans. It's a fascinating dynamic that adds a whole new layer to Murderbot's character development.

Of course, it wouldn't be a Murderbot Diaries book without some serious action. As our protagonist digs deeper into the terraforming project, it uncovers a web of deceit that puts both it and the humans it's reluctantly protecting in danger. Expect some edge-of-your-seat moments as Murderbot navigates threats both physical and ethical.

I can say that "Rogue Protocol" takes the series in some exciting new directions. The stakes are higher, the ethical dilemmas thornier, and the action even more intense. Plus, there are some revelations that'll make you rethink everything you thought you knew about Murderbot and its world. So, grab your favorite snacks (Murderbot would approve), find a cozy spot, and get ready for another wild adventure.
synopsis: SciFi's favorite antisocial A.I. is again on a mission. The case against the too-big-to-fail GrayCris Corporation is floundering, and more importantly, authorities are beginning to ask more questions about where Dr. Mensah's SecUnit is.

name: Artifical Condition
description: It has a dark past – one in which a number of humans were killed. A past that caused it to christen itself "Murderbot". But it has only vague memories of the massacre that spawned that title, and it wants to know more.
Teaming up with a Research Transport vessel named ART (you don't want to know what the "A" stands for), Murderbot heads to the mining facility where it went rogue.
What it discovers will forever change the way it thin...
review: Ah, "Artificial Condition"! You're in for a real treat if you enjoyed "All Systems Red." This second installment in The Murderbot Diaries takes our favorite SecUnit on a whole new adventure, and trust me, it's a wild ride from start to finish. It can be picked up directly too but it would be much more fun with knowing All Systems Red.

So, Murderbot's back, and this time it's on a personal mission by its own choice. After the events of the first book, our protagonist is determined to uncover the truth about its past. There's a particular incident that's been nagging at Murderbot - a mysterious event that left a lot of humans dead, but which Murderbot can't fully remember. Intriguing, right?

This quest leads Murderbot to the place where the incident supposedly took place. But getting there isn't exactly a cakewalk when you're a rogue SecUnit trying to avoid detection. That's where things start to get really interesting. Enters a new character that I think you're going to love - an AI-controlled research transport. The dynamic between these two is absolutely priceless. Imagine two incredibly intelligent, snarky AIs trying to out-sass each other while reluctantly becoming friends. It's comedy gold, I tell you.

As Murderbot gets closer to its goal, it has to go undercover as an augmented human. Now, if you remember how socially awkward our SecUnit is, you can probably imagine how hilariously that goes. Watching Murderbot navigate human interactions is both funny and oddly heartwarming.

But of course, this wouldn't be a Murderbot story if things went according to plan. As our protagonist digs deeper into its past, it uncovers a web of corporate intrigue and dangerous secrets. What I really love about this book is how it builds on the themes from the first one. We get to explore more about identity, free will, and what it means to be human (or not human, as the case may be). Murderbot's journey isn't just about uncovering the truth - it's about figuring out who and what it wants to be now that it's free.

Martha Wells continues to expand her fascinating universe in this book. We get a deeper look at the corporate-dominated future where AIs and augmented humans are commonplace. It's a world that feels eerily plausible at times.

Without giving too much away, I can say that "Artificial Condition" takes everything you loved about "All Systems Red" and cranks it up a notch. The stakes are higher, the mysteries deeper, and the character development even more satisfying. So, get ready for another adventure with our favorite SecUnit. Just be warned - you might find yourself looking at your smart devices a little differently after this. Who knows, maybe your coffee maker has been judging your beverage choices all along!
synopsis: It has a dark past – one in which a number of humans were killed. A past that caused it to christen itself "Murderbot". But it has only vague memories of the massacre that spawned that title, and it wants to know more.

name: All Systems Red
description: In a corporate-dominated spacefaring future, planetary missions must be approved and supplied by the Company. Exploratory teams are accompanied by Company-supplied security androids, for their own safety.
But in a society where contracts are awarded to the lowest bidder, safety isn't a primary concern.

On a distant planet, a team of scientists are conducting surface tests, shadowed by their Company-supplied ‘droid — a self-aware SecUnit that has hacked its own governor module, and refers to itself (though never out loud) as "Murderbot." Scornful of humans, all it really wants is to be left alone long enough to figure out who it is.
But when a neighboring mission goes dark, it's up to the scientists and their Murderbot to get to the truth.
review: "All Systems Red" by Martha Wells is a delightfully surprising and engaging sci-fi novel that will captivate you with its unique premise, rich world-building, and thought-provoking exploration of artificial intelligence. This is the first book in the series "The Murderbot Diaries" and I just love it.

The story follows Murderbot, a self-aware security robot with a deadpan sense of humor and a hobby for binge-watching entertainment videos. Despite its intimidating definition, Murderbot is a endearingly relatable protagonist, struggling with its own sense of identity and autonomy in a world that views it as a mere machine.

Wells masterfully blends action, suspense, and humor as Murderbot finds itself embroiled in a series of existence(doesn't have a life) threatening adventures alongside a group of human scientists exploring a remote planet. The tension builds as the team encounters hostile alien lifeforms, corporate conspiracies, and the ever-present threat of Murderbot's true nature being discovered.

What truly sets "All Systems Red" apart is Wells' ability to integrate complex scientific concepts and futuristic technologies into the narrative without ever overwhelming the reader. The author's way of handling the topics such as artificial intelligence, cybernetics, and space exploration adds a rich layer of authenticity and depth to the story, leaving you both entertained and educated.

The hidden gem in this thrilling plot is the exploration of what it means to be sentient, to have free will, and to forge one's own identity in a world that seeks to define and control you. Murderbot's internal struggles and growing self-awareness are handled with remarkable nuance and sensitivity, allowing readers to empathize with its plight on a deeply emotional level.

As the story progresses, you'll find yourself eagerly anticipating each new revelation and plot twist, all while marveling at the intricate worldbuilding and the thoughtful examination of complex philosophical and ethical questions.

"All Systems Red" is a true gem of a book, blending seamlessly action, humor, and the sci-fi into a package that is both immensely entertaining and intellectually stimulating. Whether you're a seasoned sci-fi reader or a newcomer to the genre, this novel is sure to leave a lasting impression.
synopsis: In a corporate-dominated spacefaring future, planetary missions must be approved and supplied by the Company. Exploratory teams are accompanied by Company-supplied security androids, for their own safety.

name: Girl in Ice
description: Valerie "Val" Chesterfield is a linguist trained in the most esoteric of disciplines: dead Nordic languages. Her twin brother Andy, an accomplished climate scientist stationed on a remote island off Greenland's barren coast. But Andy is gone: a victim of suicide, having willfully ventured unprotected into 50 degree below zero weather. Val is inconsolable. She suspects foul play.

When Wyatt, Andy's fellow researcher in the Arctic, discovers a scientific impossibility­—a young girl frozen in the ice who thaws out alive, speaking a language no one understands—Val is his first call...
review: Oh, you're in for a chilling ride with "Girl in Ice" by Erica Ferencik! This book is a perfect blend of mystery, science, and adventure that'll keep you on the edge of your seat. This was a completely random find in goodreads.

Let's set the scene: In the harsh, unforgiving landscape of Greenland, our protagonist, Val Chesterfield, is a linguist who's been struggling with anxiety and grief. She's thrust into an extraordinary situation when she's called to a remote Arctic research station. Why? Well, here's where things get really interesting. A young girl has been found. But not just any girl - she was thawed out of the ice, and against all odds, she's alive. The kicker? She's speaking a language that no one can understand. This is where Val's expertise comes in handy.

As Val tries to communicate with this mysterious ice girl, she's also grappling with personal demons. Her twin brother, Andy, died at this very research station not long ago. Was it an accident? Suicide? Or something more sinister? Val's determined to find out, adding another layer of mystery to this already complex story. The setting itself is almost a character in its own right. Ferencik paints a vivid picture of the Arctic - beautiful, deadly, and full of secrets. You can almost feel the biting cold and see the endless expanses of ice and snow as you read. I personally definitely felt it.

But it's not just about solving mysteries. The book digs into some big questions. What are the limits of human survival? How far would you go to uncover the truth? And what secrets might be hiding in the rapidly changing Arctic landscape?

As Val works to unlock the ice girl's language and story, she finds herself facing dangers she never imagined. The hostile environment is just the beginning. There are also complex dynamics among the researchers at the station, and the looming threat of what the ice girl's existence might mean for science and the world at large.

The pacing is spot-on, alternating between quiet, tense moments and heart-pounding action. Ferencik keeps you guessing, dropping breadcrumbs of information that'll have you forming theories, only to destroy them in the next chapter.

What's really fascinating is how the book blends elements of different genres. It's part survival thriller, part linguistic puzzle, part climate fiction, and part good old-fashioned mystery. And somehow, the author has done a fantastic job at it.As the story unfolds, you'll find yourself totally invested in Val's journey - both her external quest to communicate with the ice girl and solve the mystery of her brother's death, and her internal struggle to overcome her fears and find her strength.

Without giving too much away, I can say that this book will take you on a journey full of surprises. It's the kind of book that'll make you look at the world a little differently.So, if you're ready for a story that'll give you chills in more ways than one, "Girl in Ice" is the book for you. It's a fresh, unique take on the thriller genre that'll keep you guessing until the very end. Happy reading, and maybe keep a warm blanket nearby - you might need it!
synopsis: Valerie "Val" Chesterfield is a linguist trained in the most esoteric of disciplines: dead Nordic languages. Her twin brother Andy, an accomplished climate scientist stationed on a remote island off Greenland's barren coast. But Andy is gone: a victim of suicide, having willfully ventured unprotected into 50 degree below zero weather. Val is inconsolable. She suspects foul play.

name: Salvation of a Saint
description: Yoshitaka, who was about to leave his marriage and his wife, is poisoned by arsenic-laced coffee and dies. His wife, Ayane, is the logical suspect—except that she was hundreds of miles away when he was murdered. The lead detective, Tokyo Police Detective Kusanagi, is immediately smitten with her and refuses to believe that she could have had anything to do with the crime. His assistant, Kaoru Utsumi, however, is convinced Ayane is guilty. While Utsumi's instincts tell her one thing, the facts of the case are another matter. So she does what her boss has done for years when stymied—she calls upon Professor Manabu Yukawa.
review: If you enjoyed "The Devotion of Suspect X", you're in for another treat with "Salvation of a Saint" by Keigo Higashino. This book brings back our brilliant physicist, Manabu Yukawa, also known as Detective Galileo, for another intricate puzzle that'll keep you guessing until the end.

The story kicks off with a perfect murder. Yoshitaka Mashiba is found dead in his home, poisoned by arsenic-laced coffee. The prime suspect? His wife, Ayane Mashiba, who happens to be hundreds of miles away when the murder occurs. Talk about an airtight alibi!

Enter Detective Kusanagi, who's tasked with unraveling this baffling case. He's convinced that Ayane is somehow involved, despite her rock-solid alibi. But as he digs deeper, he finds himself increasingly drawn to the elegant and enigmatic Ayane. This is where things get really interesting - his growing attraction to the suspect starts to cloud his judgment.

Feeling stuck, Kusanagi reluctantly turns to his old friend and occasional rival, Manabu Yukawa. Now, if you remember Yukawa from "The Devotion of Suspect X", you know we're in for some serious intellectual fireworks. Yukawa approaches the case with his unique blend of scientific reasoning and deductive logic, peeling back layers of deception to get at the truth.

What makes this book so gripping is the way Higashino plays with the classic "locked room" concept. We know who the victim is, we have a pretty good idea of who the culprit might be, but the how is what keeps you turning pages well into the night. You know there's a logical explanation, but you just can't figure out how it's done.

The narrative switches between different perspectives, giving us insights into the investigation from multiple angles. We get to see Kusanagi's internal struggle, Yukawa's analytical approach, and even glimpses into the lives of the suspects and witnesses. This multi faced view adds depth to the story and keeps you on your toes as you try to piece together the puzzle alongside the characters.

As the investigation progresses, we're drawn into a mess of complex relationships and hidden motives. Everyone seems to have a secret, and nothing is quite as straightforward as it initially appears.One of the most intriguing aspects of the book is the battle of wits between Yukawa and the unseen killer. It's like watching a high-stakes chess match where the pieces are clues and deductions. Yukawa's scientific mind is put to the test as he grapples with a crime that seems to defy the laws of physics and probability.

The cultural backdrop of contemporary Japan adds another layer of interest to the story. Higashino paints a vivid picture of Japanese society, touching on themes of marriage, loyalty, and the clash between tradition and modernity. As you progress through the book, you'll find yourself constantly re-evaluating your theories. Just when you think you've got it all figured out, Higashino throws another curveball that crumbles the whole theory.

"Salvation of a Saint" is more than just a whodunit - it's a howdunit that will challenge your mind and keep you engaged until the very last page. If you're looking for a mystery that combines intellectual stimulation with emotional depth, you're in for a real treat. Get ready to match wits with Detective Galileo once again!

When Detective Kusanagi of the Tokyo Police tries to piece together the events of that day, he finds himself confronted by the most puzzling, mysterious circumstances he has ever investigated. Nothing quite makes sense, and it will take a genius to understand the genius behind this particular crime...
review: "The Devotion of Suspect X" by Keigo Higashino is a mystery novel that promises an exciting read. One of my friend suggested my Salvation of Saint but when I went to look for that book, found out that this is the first book in Detective Galelio series hence picked it up

The story centers around a shocking murder that sets the stage for a captivating chess game between two brilliant individuals: Ishigami, a reclusive mathematician, and Yukawa, a physics professor with a knack for solving mysteries. Their intellectual duel unfolds in a thrilling manner, keeping readers on the edge of their seats as they navigate through a web of deception and intrigue.

Higashino's meticulous attention to detail and clever plotting are evident throughout the narrative. Every character, action, and clue is intricately woven into the story, creating a complex and immersive reading experience. As you go further in the book, you're excited to unravel the mysteries and uncover the hidden truths that lie beneath the surface.

The characters are well-developed and multi-dimensional, each with their own motivations and secrets. Their interactions and relationships add depth to the story. As you anticipate delving into the book, you're intrigued by its exploration of moral and ethical dilemmas. The blurred lines between justice and morality, loyalty and sacrifice, promise to challenge your beliefs and provoke thought long after you've finished reading.

Overall, "The Devotion of Suspect X" holds the promise of being a thrilling and intellectually stimulating read. With its intriguing plot, complex characters, and thought-provoking themes, you will be immersed in the world of this acclaimed mystery novel and discover the twists and turns that lie ahead.

name: Manacled
description: Harry Potter is dead. In the aftermath of the war, in order to strengthen the might of the magical world, Voldemort enacts a repopulation effort. review: "Manacled" by SenLinYu is a really interesting fan-made story set in the Harry Potter world. It's kind of dark and intense, but it makes you feel a lot of emotions. Even if you've never read fan fiction before, this book is a big eye-opener. It tells a unique story that doesn't fit neatly into one genre, and it's even better than you might expect.

The story in this book follows an alternate version of the Wizarding World where the story goes off track with the defeat of Harry Potter which is not so unexpected if we start thinking about logical possibilities he could have died in the original books. In this unique turn readers are shown despair, struggle and oppression which is beautifully put together with beauty, tenderness and the human spirit while facing devastating scenarios.

The attention to detail  is really good with its unsettling feeling all the time  but will not let you worry too much at the same time. During the whole time I was reading the novel it felt as if the line between heroes and villains was blurry and the whole power had shifted in the wizarding world.

Those who want to try a fresh and daring perspective on the Harry Potter world, "Manacled" is an absolute must-read. It might seem dark and gloomy as you start through it but try to go through with it. Even though I have a lot of things to say about the book, some spoilers might be told so I won't be saying anything else about it. But if the concept intrigues you even a little bit you can definitely give it a try.

name: Harry Potter and The Cursed Child
description: The eighth story, nineteen years later...
It was always difficult being Harry Potter, and it isn't much easier now that he is an overworked employee of the Ministry of Magic, a husband, and a father of three school-age children.

While Harry grapples with a past that refuses to stay where it belongs, his youngest son, Albus, must struggle with the weight of a family legacy he never wanted. As past and present fuse ominously, both father and son learn the uncomfortable truth: sometimes, darkness comes from unexpected places.
review: I was so happy when I got to know another book came out in the Harry Potter series. As soon as I found this book in kolkata I was like why this looks different than the other books, only to realize this was written as a play and JK Rowling wrote it with Jack Thorne and John Tiffany. I was not fond of play's but I wouldn't give up on this novel and read it. This picks up the story nearly 2 decades after the original series and I must say it's a treat for the fans, especially science fiction fans.

The plot follows Harry's youngest son, Albus severus potter who we got shown in the final movie's ending scene, as he struggles to live up to his family's legendary legacy. The script format feels unnatural in the beginning but as you continue to read it, it grows on you.

What truly made it remarkable is how seamlessly "The Cursed Child" integrates with the established canon, expanding upon the original stories in clever and unexpected ways. Familiar faces make triumphant returns, and their interactions with the next generation of heroes are both heartwarming and thought-provoking. You also get to see a whole lot of different sides of the characters as they grow into adults compared to the original series.

The story explores profound themes of legacy, self-discovery, and the power of choice, all while maintaining the sense of wonder and adventure that made the Harry Potter series so beloved. Readers will be delighted by the clever knots to past events, as well as the introduction of new characters.

All the original series lovers might feel like this book is a fan fiction because the writing style is a bit different from the original series but still this has its own pros and cons so consider giving it a read. As a science fiction fan myself I love the concept used in this book which I don't want to spoil but in conclusion definitely worth the read.

name: Harry Potter and The Deathly Hallows
description: Harry has been burdened with a dark, dangerous and seemingly impossible task: that of locating and destroying Voldemort's remaining Horcruxes. Never has Harry felt so alone, or faced a future so full of shadows. But Harry must somehow find within himself the strength to complete the task he has been given. He must leave the warmth, safety and companionship of The Burrow and follow without fear or hesitation the inexorable path laid out for him...
review: The final installment of the beloved Harry Potter series is an absolute masterpiece! Rowling brilliantly weaves together plot threads left dangling from previous books, providing exhilarating revelations and answers long-awaited by eager fans.

The story follows Harry Potter, Ron Weasley, and Hermione Granger as they embark on a dangerous quest to destroy Voldemort's Horcruxes, tying him to his immortality. Their thrilling adventure is filled with narrow escapes, shocking betrayals, and hard-earned victories against the gathering forces of darkness. The characters face their greatest trials yet as they confront their fears and embrace their destinies. Our Trio's friendship is tested as they navigate love, loss, and the ultimate battle between good and evil.

Reading the book allows fans to uncover layers of complexity and intricate subplots that couldn't be fully explored on screen. Memorable moments, such as the Battle of Hogwarts and the revelation of some character's past, add depth and texture to the narrative. The main highlight of this book I would say is connecting all dots and getting the clear picture of the whole series. The number of times I got surprised was just damn!!

The movies tried its best to convey this book over 2 books, So these movies have more details compared to other books in the series. Every scene in the movie has a much more detailed chapter in the book which makes reading this one so much more fun. In nutshell I would say long-standing mysteries are finally unraveled, delivering emotionally-charged revelations about characters' origins, motivations, and the choices that shape their roles in the climactic battle between good and evil.
In conclusion I would definitely say not to miss this book in the series. Just as we thought it would be the last book in the series, we got the 8th book.

description: It is the middle of the summer, but there is an unseasonal mist pressing against the windowpanes. Harry Potter is waiting nervously in his bedroom at the Dursleys' house in Privet Drive for a visit from Professor Dumbledore himself. One of the last times he saw the Headmaster was in a fierce one-to-one duel with Lord Voldemort, and Harry can't quite believe that Professor Dumbledore will actually appear at the Dursleys' of all places. Why is the Professor coming to visit him now? What is it that cannot wait until Harry returns to Hogwarts in a few weeks' time? Harry's sixth year at Hogwarts has already got off to an unusual start, as the worlds of Muggle and magic start to intertwine...
review: "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire," "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix," and "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" are the fourth, fifth, and sixth installments in J.K. Rowling's iconic series. Since I don't talk much about the plot of the novels, I'm merging my reviews of all three and of the three, Order of the Phoenix is my personal favorite

In "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire", Harry returns to Hogwarts for his fourth year, where he unexpectedly finds himself competing in the dangerous Triwizard Tournament. As he navigates the challenges of the tournament, he also grapples with growing up, complex friendships, teenage problems and the looming threat of Voldemort's return. Reading the book allows fans to uncover layers of complexity and intricate subplots that couldn't be fully explored on screen. There are some moments such as Quidditch World Cup and the Yule ball which give more depth and texture to the narrative.

"Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix" follows Harry's fifth year at Hogwarts and the problems he experiences, including as the growing power of Voldemort's followers, Dolores Umbridge's (that one character which every harry potter fan will hate to the core) repressive rule, and his own inner turmoil. Dolores Umbridge, the villain that every Harry Potter fan will detest, is the book's primary centerpiece. In order to provide readers with a more comprehensive knowledge of the people and their overarching motivations, the book explores themes of rebellion, grief, and the strength of friendship.

As Harry discovers more about Voldemort's past and the Horcruxes that contain a portion of his soul, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" advances his quest. As tensions rise and the threat of Voldemort's return looms larger, Harry, Ron, and Hermione must navigate love, loss, and betrayal. This book seemed dark to me when I first watched the movie, but the characters, their conflicts and all the things put together makes this a very good read. The book's exploration of identity, sacrifice, and the consequences of choices offers readers a chance to reflect on their own lives and values.

Finally, after seeing the films, it's exciting to go back and reread "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire," "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix," and "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" in anticipation of discovering subtler details and exciting new information. Readers can relive the magic of the wizarding world and gain a fresh perspective on the story's depth through these books.

Now he has escaped, leaving only two clues as to where he might be headed: Harry Potter's defeat of You-Know-Who was Black's downfall as well. And the Azkaban guards heard Black muttering in his sleep, "He's at Hogwarts . . . he's at Hogwarts."
review: "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Askaban" is the third book in the series. Honestly the movie adaptation of this book didn't exactly leave a good impression on me, as it felt dark and gloomy all over compared to the first two which were bright and cheerful. But the content was very beautiful as it started revealing some of the plot points which would be crucial later on.

The story again continues around Harry Potter who is starting his third year in Hogwarts School and Witchcraft and Wizardry. The plot starts with obviously Sirius Black, the prisoner of azkaban who broke out of the prison, which was supposed to be the unbreakable prison. It is made known that the prisoner was a follower of voldemort who is after Harry. As we can expect instead of being wary or cautious harry doesn't break a sweat about it, Until the relationship between sirius and harry is revealed.

Who is the infamous Sirius Black, who escaped from the notorious wizard prison Azkaban? And what could the fugitive Black possibly want with Harry? Harry, Ron and Hermione, spend another year at Hogwarts, where Harry learns far more about his past then he could have expected. The readers are also introduced with new characters like Professor Lupin and new creatures called Dementors.

This book is undoubtedly darker than the previous ones, as Harry learns more and more about the sinister forces that threaten the wizarding world. The characters begin to get more developed and more complex, and a lot more interesting. Sometimes as you read and find something which seems like it was mentioned before you'll be skimming through it again, finding seemingly obvious clues, thinking 'How did I miss that?!'.
In conclusion this book gives more information about Harry's past and what exactly had happened in the past. If you have read until here, you can finish the rest of the books too.

review: "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" is the second book in JK Rowling's series. After the bright first one, this one is a bit dull I would consider, but some interesting pieces of the series come up so I think that makes up for it. In the previous book, he spent one year in Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. As almost all books are written in the same way, I'll only discuss the plot.

Harry, along with friends Ron and Hermione, try to take it upon themselves to uncover the truth behind the attacks and the chamber.

So during the whole second year, things such as Harry being a parselmouth makes him a suspect of being the heir of slytherin as the news that the heir of slytherin is the reason all the petrifications are happening around the school. The trio tries to get together to fight but at the end Hermione is the one who gives crucial info regarding what was causing the petrification. Also, I have to mention the new Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher, Gilderoy Lockhart—a self-obsessed, over-the-top character who brings plenty of laughs but also a fair bit of frustration.

In conclusion this book gives an intro to the voldemort mentioned in the first book and some part of his history. Anyone who likes fantasy stories can definitely read this series, if you haven't already

review: "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" is a tale which introduces readers to a captivating world of wizards and witches. I started reading the series after watching the movies so I basically picked up the series to get all the details which were missed or hidden. Many people already know the series, but for people who don't know you can continue reading. The book is filled with intricate details, character development, and magical lore that provide a deeper understanding of the wizarding universe. It's these little nuggets of information that were necessarily omitted in the film adaptation but add layers of complexity to the narrative.

The plot goes around a young orphaned Harry Potter who discovers on his eleventh birthday that he is a wizrd and has been accepted to Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. As he goes on this journey he learns about his tru heritage, makes new friends and encounters the antagonizing force that threatens the wizarding world.

This particular part might not be for people who haven't read the book but I was extremely disappointed with how they modified the characters in the movies. The characters really come to life in the book, Harry's bravery and sense of justice with his occasional dumbness proving why he wasn't in ravenclaw, Hermione's intelligence wittiness and loyalty and Ron's humor and bravery are more pronounced in the novel. Readers are also shown the inner thoughts and motivations of the characters, making them feel like old friends.

The writing style was engaging and imaginative, making it very easy to visualize the whole setting and the characters (though I feel it's difficult for people who have seen the movies). The book's theme is based on friendship, bravery and the battle between good and evil resonate more powerfully in the written form.

In conclusion, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is a delightful read especially for those who have enjoyed the movie adaptation. It offers the change to rediscover the magic of the wizarding world and savor the little details omitted. Whether you're a longtime fan or newcomer to the series, reading the book is an exciting and immersive journey into the HP realm.

name: Concrete Island
description: On a day in April, just after three o'clock in the afternoon, Robert Maitland's car crashes over the concrete parapet of a high-speed highway onto the island below, where he is injured and, finally, trapped. What begins as an almost ludicrous predicament in Concrete Island soon turns into horror as Maitland - a wickedly modern Robinson Crusoe - realizes that, despite evidence of other inhabitants, this doomed terrain has become a mirror of his own mind. Seeking the dark outer rim of the everyday, Ballard weaves private catastrophe into an intensely specular allegory
review: "Concrete Island" by J.G. Ballard is a gripping and disorienting tale of survival and isolation that will leave readers both intrigued and perplexed. The story follows Robert Maitland, a wealthy architect, who finds himself trapped on a small patch of land between busy highways after a car accident. Stranded and injured, Maitland must grapple with the harsh realities of urban isolation and the struggle to survive in this unforgiving environment.

The plot is both fascinating and confounding. Ballard's writing style is immersive, drawing readers into the strange and claustrophobic world that Maitland finds himself in. As the story unfolds, readers are taken on a surreal journey through Maitland's mind, as he tries to make sense of his predicament and find a way to escape.

The confusion of the plot is intentional, mirroring Maitland's own state of mind and his struggle to understand what has happened to him. Ballard expertly plays with themes of alienation, urban decay, and the breakdown of societal norms, creating a thought-provoking and haunting narrative.

Maitland's character is complex, and readers may find themselves both sympathizing with and questioning his actions. As he adapts to his new environment, his perspectives and values shift, and he begins to see the world in a different light.

Throughout the book Ballard's exploration of the human psyche and the thin line between civilization and savagery is compelling. The book challenges readers to question their own perceptions of reality and the consequences of being isolated from society.

The writing style is sharp and evocative, effectively conveying the sense of disorientation and unease that permeates the story. The vivid descriptions of the desolate landscape and the deteriorating urban environment add to the book's atmospheric and haunting ambiance.

In conclusion, "Concrete Island" is a captivating and disorienting novel that leaves readers questioning the boundaries of sanity and the human will to survive. While the plot may be confusing at times, this confusion is an essential part of the reading experience, as it mirrors the psychological journey of the protagonist. If you enjoy thought-provoking and atmospheric tales that challenge your perceptions of reality, "Concrete Island" is a book that will stay with you long after you've turned the last page.

review: One word Cute! The Map of Tiny Perfect Things, its as the name suggests. The reason I picked this was because I saw the Sci Fi in the genres of the book. It's also unique in its own way. As I said this is a cute book, regarding Mark and Margaret who relives the same day again and again. As they navigate this phenomenon, they embark on a journey to find all the tiny perfect things hidden in their repetitive day.

The story goes on in such a way that, emotions keep on changing from curiosity, interesting, happy, expecting, sad and again happy. So in short an emotional ride wouldn't want to saw rollercoaster. Once Mark and Margaret find each and discover one of the tiny perfect things, they get together to compile a map of all beautiful instances that occur throught the day they are stuck in.The characters in the book are endearing with their own quirks and insecurities. Marks observant nature compliments margaret's sense of wonder and curiosity. Their interactions are filled with charm and warmth, making their growing connection all the more heartwarming.

While romance plays a significant role in the story, "The Map of Tiny Perfect Things" also explores themes like self discovery, friendship and the significance of living in the present moment. The time loop serves as a metaphor for the repetitive nature of life and also the importance of finding joy in the small seemingly insignificant moments that make life special.

As a sci fi enthusiast, I was delighted by the book's inventive premise and exploration of time loops and its unique approach to touch the themes i talked about before. The way in which Mark and Margaret approach their unique situation is both imaginative and clever, keeping the reader intrigued and entertained throughout. The writing style is engaging and lighthearted, perfectly suited to the whimsical tone of the story. The descriptive prose brings the world to life, and the reader feels drawn into the enchanting atmosphere of Mark and Margaret's adventure.

In conclusion, "The Map of Tiny Perfect Things" is a delightful and charming sci fi romance that will leave readers with a smile on their faces. This book definitely offers a unique reading experience. Whether you're a fan of romance, sci-fi or just looking for heartwarming story with a touch of whimsy, this book is sure to captivate and leave you pondering the beauty of life's tiny perfect moments.
synopsis: Mark is 17-years-old and trapped in a time loop, and that's just fine with him. It's summertime and he's spending this one infinitely repeating day reading his way through the town library. Then he discovers someone else in the loop with the brilliant, haunted Margaret. Together Mark and Margaret set out to find every wonderful, amazing, perfect thing that happens in that one day

name: The Cheat Sheet
description: Hi, my name is Bree Camden, and I'm hopelessly in love with my best friend and star quarterback Nathan Donelson (so is half of America, judging by the tabloids and how much the guy dates). The first step is admitting, right? Except, I can never admit it to him because he clearly doesn't see me that way, and the last thing I want is for things to get weird between us.
Nothing but good old-fashioned, no-touching-the-sexiest-man-alive, platonic friendship for us! Everything is exactly how I like it! Yes. Good. (I'm not crying, I'm just peeling an onion.)
review: Is it ever too late to leave the friend zone? I was intrigued by the title of the book. The "Cheat Sheet" is the first romance novel I read. This book is a best friend to lovers trope, but the journey throught is main focus. I didn't know what exactly to expect hence I didn't keep any expectations. Thie review has a bit of spoilers, for those who dont want to be spoiled skip this.

The story revolves around Bree Camden and Nathan Donelson who have been best friends since high school. Bree is a former ballerina, who started her own dance studio after she met with an accident. Her dream is give you girls an outlet whether they can afford tution or not, but in the process she's barely scraping by for her expense. Nathan is star quarterback of an NFL football team, he's a down to earth, sweet, loyal and loving guy. He lives in a beautiful sprawling home with a gloriously huge kitchen and everything. Thats enough of character information.

So basically both have been in love with each other but didnt want to ruin their friendship hence stayed silent about it, until one night drunk Bree blurts it out in a video which goes viral. After this they enter a fake relationship for the media and whatnot. The best part about this book was the humorous way narrative and different points of view from both Bree and Nathan. The supporting characters play a very decent role in the plot. Nathan's teammates are the reason for the title of the book. They create a list of things to do to see if Bree is really into him (the so called Cheat Sheet) during the time of their fake relationship.

The relationship between the protagonists and the supporting characters is beautiful. Other than Nathan's teammates, there is Bree's sister, stylist Dylan who helps in a lot of times for the public appearances and stage instagram photos. The whole narrative, plot, misunderstandings and the story is charming and heartwarming. Even though the main genre of the book is romance, its not particularly cheesy or anything and with the humour it turns out to be way better than expected.

In conclusion, The Cheat Sheet is a charming friends to lovers romance novel. The author's way of writing makes it worth reading with different perspectives of the main characters. I personally consider this to fall under romantic comedy rather than romance, but it satisfies the fans of both categories. Overall, "The Cheat Sheet" is a sweet and enjoyable read that will leave readers feeling warm and fuzzy inside.

name: Death on the Nile
description: The tranquility of a cruise along the Nile was shattered by the discovery that Linnet Ridgeway had been shot through the head. She was young, stylish, and beautiful. A girl who had everything . . . until she lost her life.

Hercule Poirot recalled an earlier outburst by a fellow passenger: "I'd like to put my dear little pistol against her head and just press the trigger." Yet in this exotic setting nothing is ever quite what it seems.
review: "Death on the Nile" by Agatha Christie is a captivating and intriguing woven mystery novel that will keep readers on the edge of their seats. As someone familiar with Agatha Christie's works, I can confidently say that this book is another masterful creating by the Queen of Crime.

The Story unfolds on a luxurious cruise down the Nile River, where a group of passengers finds themselves embroiled in a tangled web of jealousy, deceit and murder. The book introduces a cast of diverse and intriguing characters, each with their own secrets and motives. As the body count rises, renowned detective Hercule Poirot is called upon to unravel the complex puzzle and identify the cunning killer among them.

Agatha's writing style is elegant and precise, immersing readers in the luxuriousness of the setting while subtly hinting at the darkness that lies beneath. The plot os meticulously crafted, with carefully placed clues and red herrings that will keep readers guessing until the final reveal. Her ability to create suspense and maintain a sense of tension throughout the book is truly remarkable.

Every interaction and relationship shown are integral to the plot and readers will end up trying to analyze everyone's motives and alibi, trying to piece together the puzzle. As usual, the book delves into the themes of love, betrayal and the consequences of one's actions. It explores the darker side of human nature and the lengths people will go to protect their secrets. The moral ambiguity of the characters adds depth to the story, forcing the readers to question their own judgements and assumptions.

Throughout the book, Christie's attention to detail is evident, as she expertly constructs an intricate plot with multiple layers and twists. The pacing is flawless, with moments of quiet introspection mixed with intense moments of suspense and some moments where everything feels out of control and the feel of urgency is maximum. The final reveal is satisfying, tying together all the loose ends and leaving readers in awe.

In conclusion, "Death on the Nile" is a compelling and suspenseful mystery that showcases Agatah Christie's master of the genre. The richly drawn characters, intricate plot and atmospheric setting make it a must read for fans of mystery and suspense.

name: Ready Player One
description: In the year 2044, reality is an ugly place. The only time teenage Wade Watts really feels alive is when he's jacked into the virtual utopia known as the OASIS. Wade's devoted his life to studying the puzzles hidden within this world's digital confines, puzzles that are based on their creator's obsession with the pop culture of decades past and that promise massive power and fortune to whoever can unlock them. When Wade stumbles upon the first clue, he finds himself beset by players willing to kill to take this ultimate prize. The race is on, and if Wade's going to survive, he'll have to win—and confront the real world he's always been so desperate to escape.
review: "Ready Player One" by Ernest Cline is an immersive and thrilliong science fiction novel that takes readers on a journey though a virtual reality world. As someone who watched the movie adaptation before reading the book, I was only expecting to get some details which might have been omitted in the movie but there was a surprise waiting for me. The book and movie are ways apart, Its like getting to experience the story in 2 different ways, For people who have watched the movie dont worry, this book is wholly different from it.

Set in a dystopian future where the real world has become bleak and impoverished, the majority of the people escape their harsh reality by entering OASIS, a vast virtual reality universe created by the brilliant James Halliday. When Halliday passes away, he leaves behind a challenge, whoever can solve a series of intricate puzzles and uncover hidden Easter eggs within the OASIS will inherit his immense fortune and control over the virtual world.

All of the puzzles in movies and books were completely different hence it was very satisfying to read the book. Regarding the protagonist, Wade Watts, known by his avatar name Parzival, becomes deeply invested in the quest for Halliday's Easter egg. Along with a group of fellow "gunters" (egg hunters), Wade embarks on a thrilling and perilous journey through the OASIS. The book is filled with exciting action sequences, riddles and pop culture references that will delight fans of the 80s and gaming culture.

Cline's writing style is engaging and accessible, seamlessly mixing the virtual world with the gritty reality of the character's lives. He expertly captures the sense of wonder and escapism that the OASIS offers, while also exploring the consequences of a society that relies too heavily on virtual reality.

One of the most positive aspect of "Ready Player One" is the world building. Cline has done a very good job in painting a vivid pictures of a future where OASIS has become a lifeline of billions of people, creating a rich and detailed backdrop of the story. The integration of pop culture references adds a fun element to the narrative, creating a shared excitement for readers.

Beyond the aspect of action and adventure, the novel also touches the themes of friendship, loyalty and the power of determination. Wade's journey is not just about winning the prize; It's about the process of playing, self-discovery and personal growth throughout the process. The characters, while larger than life in the virtual world, also grapple with real-world struggles and vulnerabilities, making them relatable and compelling.

In conclusion, "Ready Player One" is a thrilling and nostalgia filled sci-fi adventure that will capture the imagination of readers. Ernest Cline's detailed world building, engaging storytelling and exploration of both virtual and real world experiences make this book a must read for fans of science fiction and gaming culture and whether you've seen the movie or not, I can guarantee that reading this book will be worth it.

name: Dark Matter
description: 'Are you happy in your life?' Those are the last words Jason Dessen hears before the masked abductor knocks him unconscious. Before he awakes to find himself strapped to a gurney, surrounded by strangers in hazmat suits. Before the man he's never met smiles down at him and says, 'Welcome back.'

In this world he's woken up to, Jason's life is not the one he knows. His wife is not his wife. His son was never born. And Jason is not an ordinary college physics professor, but a celebrated genius who has achieved something remarkable. Something impossible.
review: "Dark Matter" by Blake Crouch is a mind-bending and fabulous sci-fi thriller that will leave the readers questioning their reality. People who have already had a glimpse of some topics will find this to be a very satisfying book. My friend recommended this book to me, and it's also how I first came to Blake Crouch's writings.

Regarding the story, It follows Jason Dessen, a physics professor who leads an ordinary life with his wife and son. However, everything changes when he is suddenly abducted and wakes up in a world that is eerily similar yet fundamentally different from his own. As he embarks on a desperate quest to find his way back home, He is confronted with mind bending concepts of parallel universes and the nature of identity.

Crouch's story telling is gripping, and readers will feel everything they read for sure. The plot is filled with unexpected twists and turns, and The concept of multiverse theory, where infinite versions of reality exist simultaneously and the way of accessing it as described in the book is a very intriguing way of doing it. The scientific aspects of "Dark Matter" are well-researched and explained in a way that is comprehensible to readers even those unfamiliar with the intricacies of physics.

What makes this book unique is its ability to balance the sci fi elements with human themes. As Jason grapples with the consequences of his choices and the search for his true identity, we are prompted to question the nature of the free will, the impact of our decisions and the lengths we would go to protect our loved ones. The emotional depth of the characters and their struggles adds a layer of richness to the story. Overall it creates a thought provoking experience.

As a first time reader of Blake Crouch, I was thoroughly impressed by his ability to create a suspenseful and intellectually stimulating narrative. This novel kept me busy from start to finish, constantly challenging my perceptions and leaving me pondering the implications of multiverse theory.

In conclusion, "Dark Matter" is a compelling and mind expanding science fiction novel that will leave people questioning reality and the choices we make. The way of storytelling, characters and the theme makes this novel a must read in this genre. Whether you're new to Crouch's work or already a fan, this book is a journey that will leave a lasting impression.

name: Artemis
description: Jazz Bashara is a criminal.

Well, sort of. Life on Artemis, the first and only city on the moon, is tough if you're not a rich tourist or an eccentric billionaire. So smuggling in the occasional harmless bit of contraband barely counts, right? Not when you've got debts to pay and your job as a porter barely covers the rent.

Everything changes when Jazz sees the chance to commit the perfect crime, with a reward too lucrative to turn down. But pulling off the impossible is just the start of her problems, as she learns that she's stepped square into a conspiracy for control of Artemis itself—and that now, her only chance at survival lies in a gambit even riskier than the first.
review: "Artemis" is the second Andy Weir book I have read. Its a exhilarating and gripping science fiction novel set on the moon. The story follows Jazz Bashara, a resourceful and witty smuggler who finds herself caught up in a dangerous conspiracy that coould jepordise the entire city of atermis.

Set in the not so distant future, "Artemis" paints a vivid picture of life on the moon. The city itself is a fascinating blend of science and technology, and Weir's attention to detail brings it to life. From the domed structures to the unique challenges of lunay living, the world building is immersive and believable. The next part gives a bit of spoilers regarding the flowof the story.

The plot follows Jazz our protagonist and a small time criminal gets involved in a conspiracy that puts her life and the future of Artemis at stake which quickly spirals out of control. As she navigates her way through a web of secrets, politics and personal motivations, she becomes embroiled in a plot that could have far reaching consequences for the entire moon colony. Because of how the plot is written it keeps the reader eager to uncover what is going on.

One of the main strengths of this book lies in its well developed characters, with Jazz serving as a relatable and flawed protagonist. Her sharp wit and resourcefulness make her an engaging and entertaining narrator. The supporting characters, form friends to enemies add depth and complexity to the story with their own motivations and agenda.

Weir's writing style is fast paced and engaging, filled with humour and suspense. He seamlessly integrates scientific concepts into the narrative, making the moon colony and its challenges feel plausible and immersive. The world building is also detailed and vivid. The book strikes a balance between scientific accuracy and storytelling, making it kind of educational and entertaining.

This novel explores themes of greed, corruption and the consequences of one's actions. It delves into the moral gray areas and complexities of human nature, as characters grapple with their own desites and the greater good. Jazz's journey forces her to confront these issues, adding depth and moral complexity to the plot. The novel also highlights the importance of community and loyalty in the face of adversity.

In conclusion, "Artemis": is a thrilling and captivating sci-fi adventure that will leave the readers satisfied. With its dynamic plot, well rounded characters and immersive lunar setting, the book offers a thrilling and thought provoking reading experience. Andy Weir's meticulous attention to scientific detail and his ability to create compelling narrative makes this book a must read for fans of science fiction and thrilling storytelling.
